title: Four steps to author BPMN and DMN assets on gitpod.io
content: In early 2021, , an open, flexible, and extensible cloud & desktop IDE platform, integrated support of VS Code custom editors API. It means that users would be able to run our extensions on this platform asÂ well.  Since then, we have been looking forward to seeing this feature enabled in . For those not familiar with gitpod.io, it basically provides a fully online development environment for you to work in your code on top of eclipse-theia. Learn more about Gitpod and about all its features.  Online development environments are a recent trend in the industry and can potentially be a game-changer for developers. And you can leverage that to develop your Business Automation assets. Check out how to doÂ that!  Photo by onÂ    1-) ACCESS YOURÂ CODE  The first step is to go to your repository. GitHub repository example.   2-) START GITPOD.IO  The second step is to add gitpod.io/# as prefix to your repository URL and simply openÂ it.  In my case, Iâ€™m accessing gitpod.io/#. You can also install the Gitpod which will basically do Step 2 for you with a click of a button. Once you install the extension, the button will be available in your repository.  Gitpod Chrome extension adds a button in your repository.   3-) INSTALL RED HAT BUSINESS AUTOMATION BUNDLE  The third step is to install our extensions as you would normally do on VS Code. Visualizing and authoring BPMN and DMNÂ assets.   BONUS  You can also leverage the workspace capabilities by triggering a build of your project in order to be confident that new changes are correct. To do so, simply use the provided terminal as you would use in VSÂ Code.  Since my repository has a maven project, I can run mvn clean install, which builds the project and runs theÂ tests.  Project built within Gitpod using the terminal.  I can also start up Quarkus in development mode. To do so, I can run mvn clean package quarkus:dev -DskipTests on the terminal.
